history.content:
I’m currently in 189, and I have not taken 126, 127, 110, or 16B. I have taken 16A, 54, 61A/B/C, and 70.

Workload per week has been reduced substantially since the homework assignments starting becoming shorter a few weeks into the semester. Now, homework takes up to 10 hours per week or so for me. As far as probability content, I think 70 teaches you everything you need to know for 189 (namely expectation, variance, independence, and gaussian distributions). However, you will be expected to expand the probability concepts to vectors and matrices. I’m sure that having a stronger understanding of probability helps, but I don’t think that it’s necessary to take 126 for 189.

Can’t compare to previous versions of the course very well, but I can say that the programming is very minimal. Sounds like previous semesters had much more coding involved (w/ Kaggle competitions).

----

I'm currently in 189 having taken 16A/B, 53/54, 61A/B, 70

This is the hardest class I have ever taken, and it isn't even close. 4 hours of class a week, 3 hours of homework party, 2 hours of office hours, 10-15 hours beyond that to finish the homework and write it up (much of this is gobbled by the coding problem), and 1 hour to self-grade and submit any regrade requests = 20-25 hours assuming no concept review. That's not counting the fact that 189 leans so heavily on 126 and 127 that just reading the notes on material we were supposed to have known from previous classes can easily taken another 5 hours a week.

If it were just all of this (30 hour courseload with harsh grading and difficult exams) I'd still say go for it. But it's the fact that 189 as a class is not meant to teach you the fundamentals of probability and optimization in the same ways that 126 and 127 are, that nudges me towards recommending you take 126/127 beforehand. You shouldn't sit through lecture trying to learn the math you already should have known, you should be connecting the dots between the already-familiar concept of log-likelihood and its applications in machine learning.

I’m currently in 189, and I have not taken 126, 127, 110, or 16B. I have taken 16A, 54, 61A/B/C, and 70.

Workload per week has been reduced substantially since the homework assignments starting becoming shorter a few weeks into the semester. Now, homework takes up to 10 hours per week or so for me. As far as probability content, I think 70 teaches you everything you need to know for 189 (namely expectation, variance, independence, and gaussian distributions). However, you will be expected to expand the probability concepts to vectors and matrices. I’m sure that having a stronger understanding of probability helps, but I don’t think that it’s necessary to take 126 for 189.

Can’t compare to previous versions of the course very well, but I can say that the programming is very minimal. Sounds like previous semesters had much more coding involved (w/ Kaggle competitions).

I am taking CS 170 and EECS 127 this semester. I was planning on taking CS 189 and EECS 126 next semester but it looks like I won't be able to get into 126 so I would like to know what I am getting myself into by potentially taking CS 189 with Sahai without 126.

From what I've heard, it seems as though Sahai's offering of 189 is different from previous semesters but I don't personally know anyone in the class who I can ask about it.

From what I can see on the website, it seems as though there are fewer people on course staff and a set of CS 70-style notes have replaced lecture notes and textbooks. Homework also has EE16 series style self-grades and write your own problem questions.

For students who are in the class currently: What is the workload and class like? How does the course lean on 126 knowledge?

For students on course staff and who have taken it previously: How is this version of the class different from past offerings?

For Sahai (if he's on here): I've read your answer to @3644. Were you able to apply your philosophy this semester? Can you give specific examples of how the content and structure of the course this semester are different? What changes, if any, are you going to make for next semester?

Thanks!
history.subject: How is 189 with Sahai w/o 126 and differences from past offerings of the course?
